newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: Water-logging seen cutting Zimbabwe tobacco output.
newsitem.headline: Water-logging seen cutting Zimbabwe tobacco output.

text.p: Zimbabwe's flue-cured tobacco has been hit by water-logging, and forecast production for the cropping season ending in April has been downgraded by up to 12 percent, Agriculture Minister Denis Norman said on Monday.

He said continuous rains were causing soil leaching and water-logging in many parts of the southern African country, the world's third largest producer of flue-cured tobacco after the U.S. and Brazil.
Earlier this month, the minister and industry officials forecast that Zimbabwe's tobacco output would to increase to 240 million kg this year from 200 million kg last season.
"We are getting reports of water-logging and this is pushing hard the security measures farmers have to use to maintain high quality, especially at the curing stage," Norman told state media.
"Potential yield has already been reduced by 10 to 12 percent of what could have been achieved and there is nothing much the commercial or small scale farmers can do," he added.
